div.head: The MINORITY OF St. Lewis. OR, A Relation of what happen'd of mo≈øt Memorable, under his Reign, during the Years, 1226, 1227, 1228, and 1229.
div.p:
NEver any Chri≈øtian Prince merited of Hi≈øtory more ≈øolid, ≈øerious, and univerver≈øal Prai≈øe than Lewis the 9th
of that Name, King of France, firnamed the Saint; and con≈øequently never any Chri≈øtian Prince hath been ≈øo ill treated by the generality of Hi≈øtorians, both French and Foreigners, Ancient and Modern, Good and Bad, of all ≈øorts of People, and of all Religions. The Hereticks of latter times haply offended at the Rea≈øon he gave for refu≈øing to go to ≈øee the Body of Chri≈øt become vi≈øible in the hands of a Prie≈øt, namely, that he had no need of ocular Te≈øtimony to convince him of a Truth, whereof he was already ≈øo well ≈øatisfied, have with that prejudice repre≈øented even the mo≈øt Heroick of his actions, that, were their Credit valuable, this Prince could certainly be allow'd no better a Character than any of the nine la≈øt Kings of the Merovingian Race; They will needs have that haughtine≈øs wherewith he treated his Brother Charles of Anjou, who after he was crown'd King
of Naples and Sicily let loo≈øe the Reins to licence, pa≈øs for an Effect of ≈øecret Pride and Ambition; they brand with ra≈øhne≈øs and imprudence the two Expeditions he made again≈øt the Infidels, and will have the extraordinary Charge he was at in tho≈øe Undertakings, no other than Profu≈øene≈øs and Prodigality. That Maje≈øtick Air which he expre≈øt in all his Actions, and which de≈øcended to him from the Queen his Mother, they interpret to be only a natural Surline≈øs and Au≈øterity of humour in him: and though more Covertly, they forbear not to cen≈øure his frequent Vi≈øitations, and regulations of Ho≈øpitals The plainne≈øs of his habit they attribute to a poorne≈øs of Spirit in him, and from his aptne≈øs to conceal and pa≈øs over all private Injuries offer'd him, they are ready to accu≈øe him of Pu≈øillanimity and Cowardice. His Conver≈øation though obliging enough, they account too Re≈øerv'd
and Moro≈øe, con≈øidering the Familiarity and Freedom that had been allow'd to Courtiers in tho≈øe times.

They cavil at the ≈øincerity of his An≈øwers both by word of mouth and in writing to foreign Amba≈ø≈øadors, in the Affairs he had to concert with the Crowns of England and Spain; they tax him of too much Severity in the Execution of his Laws, e≈øpecially, again≈øt the Jews, and of too much adhering to particular Ju≈øtice to the prejudice of the publick in the renuntiations he made to the Dutchy of Guien and Kingdom of Ca≈øtile.

Nor is this noble Prince and Saint King Lewis better dealt with by the Catholick Hi≈øtorians, though perhaps not with ≈øuch an apparent and de≈øign'd prejudice, and that by Rea≈øon (for a more probable cau≈øe cannot be gue≈øs'd at) of that pragmatick Sanction which came forth under the Name of this Prince, occa≈øion'd by the quarrel he had with the Court of
Rome. They look'd upon as Criminal the zealous Concerns he had for the Rights of his Crown, and upon this pretence took upon them to be≈øpatter all his actions without Limit or Di≈øtinction.

Of this la≈øt ≈øort of Writers ≈øome there are, who not daring to launch out into tho≈øe high Intemperancies, have yet fallen into another default equally di≈øadvantageous to the glory of this Royal Saint. They have a conceit for≈øooth that there is no extraordinary Sanctity to be found but in Mona≈øteries, or at lea≈øt that it is not to be attain'd but by ≈øuch Mortifications of the body as are there in u≈øe, and upon this pre≈øuppo≈øal they carry on the main part of their de≈øign throughout all their Writings, ≈øo that they make it not ≈øo much their bui≈øine≈øs to repre≈øent this holy King Lewis ≈øuch as really he was, but ≈øuch as in their Opinion he ought to have been, that is to ≈øay, in ≈øtead of
making him a great King as he was they ≈øet him forth a very Monk of the mo≈øt reformed Order. In≈øomuch that in a Manu≈øcript Imbelli≈øht with curious Figures in Miniature which came to light about 12 years after his death, he is pourtray'd in ≈øeveral Exerci≈øes of Penitence, the mo≈øt ≈øevere and bloody that were than practic'd in Cloi≈øters. Moreover, one Richard a Monk of the Abby of Enove de Votsge, de≈øcribes him yielding to the Temptation of a certain Jacobin who urg'd him to take upon him the Order of St. Dominick, and from which nothing but the powerful and ince≈ø≈øant Interpo≈øings of the Queen his Mother, Philip the Hardy his Son, and Charles of Anjou his Brother could have diverted him. Mathew Paris an Engli≈øh Benedictin, an Hi≈øtorian otherwi≈øe the mo≈øt faithful and be≈øt informed of his Time, brings in our Princely St. Lewis at his re≈øtitution
of Guien to the Engli≈øh, uttering him≈øelf in a Speech no le≈øs void of Sen≈øe then Regal Authority, and gives him a very lame at lea≈øt imprudent Character, when he tells us that without fear or re≈øpect of the Barons of his Realm he had given up to the Engli≈øh, tho≈øe other Provinces which Philip the August his Grandfather, had alienated from them in the Reign of King John, and reunited to the Crown of France.

But this is not all that hath been vented of unhand≈øome by the≈øe three above mentioned Authors, who all of them liv'd in the very Time of St. Lewis. 'Tis ≈øtrange to con≈øider how ≈øcant they are in recounting the Virtues of this Prince, as to his Quality and E≈øtate, how they bury, if I may ≈øo ≈øay, in my≈øterious ≈øilence the great Care he took to acquit him≈øelf hand≈øomly of all things that belong'd to his Kingly Office? how they ≈ømother the be≈øt part of all his mo≈øt
glorious Actions, and ≈øpeak openly of tho≈øe only which were ob≈øcurely either begun or ended? never con≈øidering all this while that David in the mid≈øt of all his plenty, and keeping a Court not differing in outward Splendor from that of other Kings, was yet a man no le≈øs at lea≈øt, if not more after Gods own heart than Racab, ob≈øerving the utmo≈øt Severities of Life which the old Law requir'd. In fine, as if this Prince were de≈øtin'd to be the Mark of all Inju≈øtice, the Modern Hi≈øtorians have almo≈øt all of them in this point follow'd the Example of the Ancients, whether it were that they only contented them≈øelves to copy them out as it were, for want of the Originals by which they were to have been ≈øupplyed and mended, or, that they cho≈øe rather to take upon Tru≈øt what they found in Print, than to be≈øtow the pains and time to ≈øearch and con≈øult Manu≈øcripts.

The de≈øign therefore of this work is to rectifie and turn to advantage the Mi≈øtakes of others, and to remove tho≈øe Inconveniences that have en≈øued upon them, at lea≈øt as far as can be done by touching upon them briefly, not having here time or place to repre≈øent all things in their full proportion; and I ≈øhall think my ≈øelf very happy, if without being wounded I can hand≈øomly make my way over ≈øo many Thorns, ≈øince doubtle≈øs there can be nothing more conducing to the Dolphins In≈øtruction than to be pre≈øented with a true Character of that per≈øon among all his Ance≈øtors, who≈øe Life next to that of the Incomparable Lewis, the 14th. it mo≈øt imports him to contemplate; and if I ≈øhould be ≈øo unhappy as not to ≈øucceed, I ≈øhall at lea≈øt gain this Advantage that the Correction of my Errors will in≈øtruct others more dextrous to arrive at a ≈øafe Haven.

St. Lewis came into the World

The Prince his Father liv'd till near 30 Years of Age a private Life, contenting him≈øelf with the Kings Grace and Favour, and the hopes of ≈øucceeding him one day, when the Cour≈øe of Nature and the Fundamental Law of the Land ≈øhould call him to the Crown. He was nam'd Lewis, and the a≈øtoni≈øhing fiercene≈øs of his Countenance in time of fight, which increas'd or dimini≈øh'd proportionally to the danger he was in procur'd him the Sirname of Lyon, however, he never re≈øembled this Animal but when he was engag'd in Military Affairs, being at other times the mo≈øt obliging and complai≈øant of all men living; not to
mention tho≈øe his other Excellencies which will afford a noble Character to him that ≈øhall undertake to write his Life: but in Relation to what hath been ≈øaid of him, one In≈øtance of his Moderation cannot be omitted, ≈øince thereby was divulg'd upon the noble≈øt Stage of Europe his readine≈øs to perform the Command of God, who promi≈øeth a Reward both in this Life and that to come, to tho≈øe who give due Honour and Obedience to their Parents.

King Philip the Augu≈øt after the death of Queen I≈øabel of Hainault his fir≈øt Wife, by whom he had Prince Lewis, e≈øpou≈øed Angelberge of Denmark, a Prince≈øs without Compare, the faire≈øt and mo≈øt virtuous Europe could boa≈øt of. But the Incon≈øtancy of Man is never ≈øo deplorable as in ≈øuch like Conjunctures, wherein he changes in a moment not only from exce≈øs of love to exce≈øs of hatred, but which is wor≈øe, from the exce≈øs of
love to the utmo≈øt Indifference. Philip, the Morrow after his Nuptials with Angelberge, entertain'd a ≈øtrange aver≈øion for her. He fir≈øt excluded her from his Bed, next from his Hou≈øe, He ≈øued out a Proce≈øs for the di≈ø≈øolution of the Marriage and found the Bi≈øhops ready enough to comply with his Re≈øolution upon pretext of an Imaginary kindred between the two Spou≈øes: upon their Sentence immediately en≈øued another Marriage of the King with Agnes of Tullet, other wi≈øe called Mary Prince≈øs of Bohemia by whom he had ≈øeveral Children: Angelberge bore her Divorce with a Patience never enough to be applauded. She not only not oppos'd the Kings de≈øign, but forbore to return into her own Country, for fear her. Pre≈øence ≈øhould animate her Relations to Revenge the Affront ≈øhe had receiv'd. All the favour ≈øhe de≈øired was that ≈øhe might be permitted to re≈øide in France, where ≈øhe led ≈øo holy
and retir'd a Life that all her Enemies, her Rival her ≈øelf not excepted, could not but admire her, and pity her Condition.

However, Canute King of Denmark thought him≈øelf oblig'd in honour, though ≈øhe oftentimes conjur'd him to the contrary, to appear for his Si≈øter Angelberge, and thereupon demanded ju≈øtice in her behalf of Pope Cele≈øtin the 3d. in≈øomuch that his Holine≈øs remon≈øtrated the whole Affair to the King by Cardinal Meilleur, who not being admitted to a favourable hearing, addre≈øs'd him≈øelf to the Prelates that attended the Court, to little purpo≈øe God knows, for all the benefit he reapt of this Negotiation was a few in≈øignificant Expre≈ø≈øions of their Compa≈ø≈øion for the Queens Misfortune; and all his Eloquence, though he was accounted the be≈øt Oratour of his time, could not obtain one ≈øtep of advancement toward the ree≈øtabli≈øhment of this
Prince≈øs. The Cardinal upon this finding none to ≈øecond him, return'd to Rome, from whence the Pope, pre≈øs'd by the continual Importunities of the Danes, ≈øent ≈øoon after into France as his Legate, Peter Cardinal of St. Mary with order to a≈ø≈øemble the Prelates of France, and to put the Realm under an Interdict, in ca≈øe the King did not within a time prefixt receive Angelberge again. The Cardinal executed this dangerous Commi≈ø≈øion with as much vigour as addre≈øs; and the King not doubting to come off by tho≈øe ≈øubterfuges that occur in formal Tryals con≈øented to the calling of a Councel at Dijon, the Capital Town of Burgundie: the matter was examined to the bottom, and the ju≈øte≈øt cau≈øe became the ≈øtronge≈øt. Tho≈øe Prelates of the Court Party who had pronounc'd the Marriage of Angelberge Null, either touch'd with remor≈øe of Con≈øcience, or finding their
Number not ≈øtrong enough to maintain it, revok'd their Sentence, and the Council actuated by the Cardinal, thundred out an Interdiction, only with this Re≈øerve that twenty dayes re≈øpite ≈øhould be allow'd to the publication of their Decree,

The King in ≈øtead of taking this limited Time to con≈øider of a Conce≈ø≈øion, rather laid hold of an advantage, thereby to make his Appeal from the Determination of the Councel, and to revenge him≈øelf of the Bi≈øhops who acted thus, as he pretended, with a malicious de≈øign of oppo≈øing his proceedings; he ≈øeis'd upon their Temporals, and to prevent the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance they might receive from their Relations, for at that time the riche≈øt Benefices in France were in the hands of per≈øons of highe≈øt quality, he po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd him≈øelf of the third part of Gentlemens E≈øtates. In the next place, Angelberge was remov'd from her pre≈øent place of Solitude,
and confin'd to the Ca≈øtle of E≈øtampes, where ≈øhe was ≈øeque≈øtred from all Society, but only of ≈øuch as were the Creatures of her Rival.

There were at that time in France ≈øcarce fewer Malecontents than Natives, and though Prince Lewis could have no lawful cau≈øe for putting him≈øelf at the Head of them, yet never could he have had a fairer and more plau≈øible pretext: He had yet neither Place of Tru≈øt nor Profit, neither Government of Town nor Province; all he had to ≈øub≈øi≈øt upon was an indifferent ≈øumme of Money which he receiv'd yearly out of Spain. He could not hope to make his Condition better while he kept him≈øelf in the Limits of due Obedience, whereas had he Headed the Malecontents, he might have a≈ø≈øur'd him≈øelf of obtaining by Articles of Accomodation what≈øoever he could have de≈øir'd, for ≈øince tho≈øe People would never have been reduc'd without
him, the King mu≈øt have been forc'd to have given them an entire Satisfaction, nor could he have avoided above all things the taking back of Angelberge.

But all this while Prince Lewis remain'd firm and un≈øhaken in that Faith and Duty which he knew to be owing to his Father, and his King, and own'd him≈øelf bound in Honour and Con≈øcience to adopt upon all accounts his Maje≈øties Intere≈øts as his own, and ≈øhewed a more than ordinary Submi≈ø≈øion at a time when all the re≈øt of his Subjects meditated a general Revolt; in ≈øhort, he gave an Example of Fidelity not to be parallel'd in the Hi≈øtory of any Nation: Nor was this unexampled Loyalty of his long without a Recompence; for having ≈øo generou≈øly and virtuou≈øly refus'd an Illegal Power he was call'd to the Crown of England by the univer≈øal con≈øent of the E≈øtates of the Realm. Three Years he there peaceably
reign'd, and when at the end thereof, the Incon≈øtancy of tho≈øe that had call'd him in unworthily retracted that Allegeance which both their duty oblig'd them to, and his Virtue; Almighty God abundantly repair'd that detriment to him two ≈øeveral wayes, the one was a perpetual E≈øtabli≈øhment of the Crown of France upon his Po≈øterity from his Elde≈øt Son, the other an Acce≈ø≈øion of the Crowns of Naples and Sicily with the Earldom of Provence which fell contrary to all Expectation to the younge≈øt of his Sons. But of the worldly Ble≈ø≈øings that attended Prince Lewis there was none he made greater account of, or took higher Satisfaction in, than the Wife which God in his mo≈øt e≈øpecial Providence be≈øtow'd upon him, viz. Blanch of Spain, the Daughter of Alphon≈øo King of Ca≈øtile, Sirnamed the Noble, a Prince≈øs who in that rude, heavy Age wherein ≈øhe had the Misfortune
to be born, po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd all tho≈øe graces which were capable to draw admiration from the mo≈øt accompli≈øh'd Ladies of her time. And as none dur≈øt di≈øpute the Prerogative of beauty with her, ≈øo it was ab≈øolutely taken for confe≈øs'd on all hands that ≈øhe infinitely ≈øurpa≈øs'd them in a Noble and Gallant Meen. The young Age wherein ≈øhe was E≈øpous'd to Lewis, for ≈øhe was then ≈øcarce ripe for Marriage, render'd her ≈øo much the more pliant and flexible in conforming to the humours and manners of the French Nation; wherein ≈øhe made ≈øo perfect an Improvement that ≈øhe could not po≈ø≈øibly have been di≈øtingui≈øh'd from a French Woman, but for that grave Severity which was too Natural to be ea≈øily quitted by her, though at a time when ≈øhe mo≈øt re≈øign'd her ≈øelf up to Complai≈øance and Familiarity, Her Air as Maje≈øtick as it was, had yet never any thing in it of di≈øobliging, being ever attended
with words and actions full of Spirit and Vivacity, and a Gaiety of humour that infinitely became her: She enjoy'd ≈øo vigorous a health of body that till that ≈øickne≈øs took her which ended her dayes, ≈øhe never was troubled with any other di≈øtemper than a ≈øhort quotidian Ague, which argued rather a ≈øtrong Con≈øtitution then any Intemperature of humours. Her beauty was not impair'd by Age, nor did the bringing of ten Children into the World any thing dimini≈øh the fre≈øhne≈øs or delicacy of her Complexion. But that which ≈øingularly recommends her above all that hath been ≈øaid is the clear judgment and exalted wit which ≈øo qualified her for bu≈øine≈øs, that ≈øhe came not ≈øhort of the mo≈øt eminent Mini≈øters of Spain, either for quick in≈øight, or prudent foreca≈øt in the weightie≈øt Affairs without the lea≈øt of that heavy ≈ølowne≈øs and irre≈øolution which hath been the fault of many,
as ≈øhe made appear by her management of tho≈øe no le≈øs difficult Tran≈øactions that hapned during her Regency, then have been known at any time; and with that Ea≈øe and di≈øpatch that ≈øhe was not ob≈øerv'd to have the lea≈øt trouble or perplexity of Spirit. Her Piety was neither ≈øuper≈øtitious, nor a Cloak for the carrying on of any Intere≈øt, and it was an excellent ≈øaying of hers to her Children when ≈øhe had their Education under her Care; That ≈øhe had rather ≈øee them buried than to abandon that purity of Life to which their Bapti≈øm had call'd them.
